https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/193980,2018,International Organizations in Theory and Practice,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. G. Avci'],,Course goals
After completing this course students are able to:
articulate the leading explanations within political science/international relations as to why IOs exist,
understand controversies surrounding IOs in the context of international relations theory,
why and how international organizations are thought to help solve global problems, and the major challenges IOs face in meeting their objectives.
to apply theoretical arguments from the IR literature to specific cases.

International Organizations are fundamental to understanding international politics. They play a major role in efforts to attain international cooperation and global governance. Yet the power, impact, and effectiveness of International Organizations differ widely – across organizations, issues, regions, and over time. A key aim of the course is to understand these differences and their implications for the solution of transnational challenges.

The course will be divided in two parts. The first part introduces central theoretical approaches that help us to understand key aspects of international organizations: their creation and design, their decision-making processes, and their impact and policy effectiveness. The second part applies this analytical toolbox to explain the role of international institutions in specific policy domains, such as security, human rights, health, environment, migration and labor rights.
In terms of institutions, while particular attention will be given to the United Nations and related agencies and programs, non-governmental and regional organizations will be discussed as well.
This course will be conducted through seminars with an emphasis on interactive teaching aimed at engaging all students in active participation. There will also be group/student-led

discussion sessions. For these group-led discussion sessions, I will assign a group of students (2-3 students) articles, which they will present together with questions that they develop based on their reading. The assigned group will be responsible for leading class discussion with puzzles and questions. Furthermore, a debate and/or simulation will be included in the course.&nbsp
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/194747,2018,International Political Economy,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. J.G.W. Blom'],,Course goals
<div>After completing the course students are able to:
<li>explain the main differences between the theoretical toolkits of the American and British School of IPE and determine and defend their own position vis-à-vis the Schools
<li>explain the main ideas, concepts and theories related to contemporary challenges in the international political economy
<li>use the theoretical toolkit of IPE to answer a topical research question and report their analysis in a scholarly manner
<li>study and critically evaluate bodies of IPE literature and disseminate your analysis through blogs, podcasts, and (online) debates&nbsp

The global political economic order is faced with crucial challenges at the current juncture. Climate change, global inequality, new economic powers rising, and a nationalist backlash to economic globalization, to name a few. The way these challenges are addressed will determine no less than the future of humanity: will citizens the world over be able to meet their aspirations and achieve their dreams? The main ideas and theories of IPE provide crucial building blocks to understand and deal with the aforementioned challenges and will enable you to come to a reasoned analysis of what might be done.
In order to develop students’ knowledge and skills in international political economy, the course will utilize lectures, student presentations, and class discussions.&nbsp
column2: Students will also prepare and write short reflective essays as well as final research paper. Teacher guidance and feedback will be provided along the way.

column1: <div>More specifically, in class discussions students will critically engage with the weekly reading materials. &nbsp
column2: They will also be expected to prepare and lead a session in class on a topic related to IPE (class chairmanship). Furthermore to develop and apply their research and writing skills, students will submit and (present) multiple short papers and a final extensive research paper. The shorter papers focus will be reflective assignments on concepts and theories in IPE.&nbsp
column3: The more extensive research paper that is designed to assess the student’s ability to develop an original IPE argument, will seek to validate the chosen argument through research and the application of analytical and critical skills. A final exam will test the students’ knowledge on the course material.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/188343,2018,International Relations in Practice,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J. Pekelder', 'drs. A.J. Boekestijn']",,"Course goals
- Learning to analyse relevant primary sources
- Learning to write primacy sources, such as resolutions, declarations and policy memos from a policy advisor's perspective in order to prepare yourself for a career in policy making
- Learning to present prepared materials orally in a simulated working situation &nbsp

This course will focus on primary sources. The students will not only learn how to interpret primary sources such as resolutions, declarations, speeches and policy memos, but they will also become a policy advisor themselves by actually creating primary sources. Rather than passively analysing other people’s sources the students will actively engage in past and current affairs and make policy themselves. This course will raise the students’ awareness of the fact that the sources they usually study merely as static historical objects have actually been part of a dynamic process, which was intended to shape the future rather than reflect the past. After selecting and studying a wide range of sources from inter alia international organisations in depth, students will write their own policy memo, resolution or declaration, while taking the political context and the relevant goals into account. At the end of the course, students will also participate in the simulation of a large international organisation, such as the UN, so as to put their knowledge of International Relations in practice.
To pass this course students are expected to attend the extracurricular Meet the Experts Seminar Series. These are meant to increase the students' &nbsp
column2: knowledge and understanding of how IR works in practice. &nbsp

column1: By learning to write policy memos, resolutions and declarations and testing and defending these in a practical working situation, and by attending and actively participate in seminars with experts from the field students prepare themselves for a career in (foreign) policy making.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/193977,2018,International Relations: dimensions of world politics,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. G van der Ree'],,Course goals
​After completing this course students are able to:

column3: know the different concepts, themes, and approaches in IR, the way they are used in the field, and how they are related to empirical questions in contemporary world politics
apply theories to current events in world politics&nbsp
study, summarise, and present a classical and/or groundbreaking work in the field of IR

column6: Assesses ability to initiate independent research combining theory (LG1, 2) and empirics (LG 5).

column4: Final paper (30%, paper): assesses ability to position oneself in the field (LG 3), apply IR theory (LG 2) and conduct a piece of original empirical research (LG 5).

column1: <div>This is an introductory course in the field of IR. It will give an overview of the plurality of the discipline, from foreign policy and institutionalism to postmodern and feminist approaches. It will focus on four aspects: theory, topics, reflexive practice, and research.&nbsp
column2: The theories and topics will be the backbone of the course, discussing different theoretical approaches and related themes every week through readings and presentations. Reflexive practice will come in the form of a simulation game, in which direct experiences will be connected to the theoretical and empirical content of the course. In the research part, students will learn how to apply IR theory meaningfully to concrete case studies.

column1: This course is mostly based on an interactive combination of student presentations, short lectures, role-playing gaming, and classroom discussions. Apart from small assignments, there will be a take-home mid-term exam and a final paper.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/193309,2018,International Strategic Management,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<body>Internationally active firms need a solid toolkit to analyse the context in which they operate. This course provides you with knowledge of modern international business economics to use for managerial decision making. It provides a general overview of trade theory including international finance, tools for country analysis, cross cultural management, and foreign market entry strategies. It also provides a solid background for analysing international strategy and organisation including supply chain management and international human resource management. Three levels are explored in-depth:

column2: including political and legal aspects, international institutional arrangements affecting international business, and cross-cultural issues and barriers
of multinational companies including international organisational issues and entry strategies, exporting strategies, and cross border cooperation and investment
including supply chain management, multinational finance and international human resource management, entrepreneurship and leadership.

column1: The course is taught with lectures and tutorials. The tutorials make intensive use of case studies in order to apply the theoretical knowledge imparted in the lectures.
<li>Foreign market entry risk assessment report and 4 HBS business case study preparations (50%, group)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192246,2018,International and European Family Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['mr. W.M. Schrama'],,"Course goals
• the student has studied selected family law issues from different perspectives, in particular a gender and a child perspective both in international law and European law (both ECHR and EU law).
• the student has in-depth knowledge of the main features of some selected family law issues in different legal systems.
• the student has developed his academic skills, in particular analytic, writing and presentation skills.

• the student has developed his critical thinking skills through teaching methods that encourage students to develop their own critical opinion on the topics addressed. In addition to lectures and reading of texts, literature and case law, weekly seminars provide the opportunity for debates, discussions and analysis of case law on current developments in family law.

<div>This course will focus on an international and comparative law perspective on family law. We will consider important and complex questions such as: What is the impact of international norms and human rights? How do we deal with new developments, such as surrogacy? We will deal with art. 8 ECHR and consider what a ""family"" is , we will reflect on (same-sex) partner relationships and on parent-child issues. How do gender, age and disabilities affect family law and what is the role of care? In addition, the course addresses private international law issues
column2: in a globalizing world, the number of international family relationships increases every year. These are some of the topics and questions addressed in this master course on International and European Family Law (IEFL). The required knowledge before being allowed to participate in this course is: BA course Personen- en familierecht/ family law. IEFL combines various legal fields, perspectives and methods such as:

column1: • Private International Law (Brussels IIbis, Rome III, MPR, Maintenance Regulation,Hague Conventions)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192311,2018,International and European Institutional Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. M. Kanetake', 'mr. dr. T. van den Brink']",,"Course goals
• the student has enhanced knowledge and understanding of issues of international and European institutional law.
• the student is able to conduct research and present the outcome of it in a written paper in English.

The institutional law of international organisations comprises those rules of law that govern their legal status, structure and functioning. Since this course is a capita selecta, a selection of the core issues in this field will be made, such as international legal personality and the powers of international organisations, their decisions and decision making, as well as the control of and by international organisations, including dispute settlement. After a thorough study of the selected issues, those issues will be analysed more in-depth with regard to one or more international organisations (for example the UN and WTO). Whilst the first half of the course will focus on international organisations in general, the second half of the course will be devoted to the European Union. The same issues will be addressed in both parts of the course. While studying the selected topics, the historical context and the societal forces that explain their existence and functioning will be discussed. The tension between the intergovernmental and supranational method of cooperation will serve as a leitmotiv throughout the entire course.
Not possible in combination with RGBOI0350 International European Institutional Law.
Place of the course within the curriculum:
Any additional requirements of the course are listed in the ""Leidraad"" of the course.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192310,2018,International and European Labour Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['mr. I. van der Helm'],,"Course goals
the student has knowledge and understanding of the main issues of international and European labour law, especially of the fundamental rights of collective bargaining, strike and equal treatment.
the student can deal with questions on direct effect of international and European labor law in national labour law.
the student can place issues in an international and European context.
the student is able to analyze, build up argumentation and present his findings in a paper in English.
the student is able to plead and present his findings during the moot court.

International and European Labour Law are gaining importance due to the process of globalisation of the economy and the ongoing integration of Europe. Moreover the recognition of the fundamental social rights on the international and European scale is resulting in a growing influence of the international and European labour law on the industrial relations and social policy of the states. So, national labour law will be increasingly shaped by international labour standards and more in particular by EC employment law.

The objective of this course is to familiarize the students from the various countries with the specific issues of the international and European labour law, its instruments and the way and forms the standards as laid down in the sever­al international legal sources, are implemented in and will affect the national legal systems.

The first one is an introduction to the principles of international and European labour law. A dispatch will be given of the important international organisations and their power and competences to establish labour standards to be implemented in the national legislation and/or recognised in the case law of the countries: the International Labour Organisation, the Council of Europe and the European Community.

The second part will deal with some substantive issues of international and European labour law. Starting point are the fundamental social rights, as recognised in UN-Treaties, The European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), The European Social Charter and the EU Charter of fundamental rights. It is about 1. The freedom of association, the right to collective bargaining and the right of workers participation in business decisions. 2. The right to equal treatment, the prohibition of discrimination in employment on grounds of sex, race, age and religion. 3. The right to collective action. 4. Dismissal.
The third and last part is a moot court, based on cases of international and/or European labour law.
Not possible in combination with RGBOI0300 International and European Labour Law.
Any additional requirements of the course are listed in the ""Leidraad"" of the course.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/194329,2018,International research project Singapore,Dutch,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. A.J. Meijer', 'dr. M.J. van der Meulen']",,"Course goals
Na afronding van deze cursus kan de student:

<li>laten zien over kennis en inzicht te beschikken in Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschappelijke vraagstukken op het gebied van innovatiemanagement en de realisatie van duurzaamheidsinitiatieven in de stad Singapore

<li>laten zien te beschikken over kennis van en inzicht in de context van Singapore, onder andere de bestuurlijke verhoudingen, sociaal-culturele verschillen en politieke geschiedenis, dat mede verkregen wordt op basis van een verblijf van meerdere weken, het verrichten van onderzoek en samenwerken in dat land
<li>laten zien hoe de kennis en inzichten over innovatiemanagement en duurzaamheidsinitiatieven in Singapore relevant kunnen zijn voor Nederland

<li>abstracte theoretische kernvragen omvormen tot concrete onderzoeksprojecten binnen het bredere onderzoeksthema en de daarvoor benodigde abstracte theoretische concepten relevant maken voor het gezamenlijk onderzoeksproject

<li>een kwalitatief onderzoek uitvoeren waarbij de data vergaard wordt in het buitenland (Singapore) en reflecteren op de betekenis van institutionele en sociaal-culturele verschillen bij het interpreteren van deze data
<li>intensief samenwerken in een duo en als onderdeel van een grotere groep met een gemeenschappelijk onderzoeksdoel en reflecteren op de daarvoor benodigde vaardigheden en verantwoordelijkheid
• zijn/haar bevindingen en analyses (op samenhangende wijze) presenteren als onderzoeksartikel dat kan worden gepubliceerd in een gezamenlijke bundel.
<li>zijn/haar bevindingen en analyses presenteren tijdens een symposium en deze duidelijk maken aan een breed publiek dat niet heeft deelgenomen aan het onderzoeksproject
• op een overkoepelend niveau meewerken aan gemeenschappelijke conclusies ten behoeve van een bundel en een symposium.

Het Research Project is een tweejaarlijks uniek en grensoverschrijdend project van de studie Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschap in samenwerking met studievereniging Perikles. Een groep van twintig studenten reist af naar een ander land. Hier doen zij in duo’s onderzoek naar actuele bestuurskundige of sociaal maatschappelijke vraagstukken in een andere cultuur. Ter voorbereiding volgen de studenten in periode 4 en periode 1 onderwijs. Het tijdspad van het Research Project is ongeveer één jaar. Het project start met de vorming van een nieuwe groep deelnemers in maart 2018 en eindigt ongeveer een jaar later met het afsluitende symposium. Het doel van het Research Project is om een groep van geselecteerde studenten kennis te laten maken met het doen van een kwalitatief empirisch onderzoek binnen een andere en vreemde context dan zij in Nederland gewend zijn. Deelname aan het Research Project door derdejaars bachelor studenten Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschap staat gelijk aan een voltijdskeuzevak (15 ECTS).&nbsp
column2: Een commissie van acht studenten houdt zich bezig met de organisatie van het Research Project.

column1: Het thema van het Research Project 2018/2019 is Sustainable Cities. De studenten zullen onderzoek gaan doen naar hoe innovatiemanagers duurzaamheidsinitiatieven organiseren in Singapore binnen een stedelijke context. Singapore heeft zich de afgelopen jaren sterk ontwikkeld en heeft zich op de kaart gezet als een van de meest duurzame steden in de wereld. Stedelijke ontwikkeling is een belangrijk onderdeel van de context voor duurzame economische groei
column2: het land Singapore bestaat namelijk grotendeels uit stad. Door de wereldwijde toename van mensen die in de stad gaan wonen, is het met het oog op de toekomst essentieel om steden houdbaar in te richten. Om de successen van Singapore te onderzoeken zal het proces: ‘van plan naar praktijk’ centraal staan. Daarbij gaan de studenten in op hoe innovatiemanagers ideeën over duurzaamheid omzetten in realiseerbare plannen. En deze met allerlei stakeholders binnen netwerken van overheden, het bedrijfsleven, burgers en maatschappelijke organisaties in praktijk brengen. Omdat duurzaamheid een steeds grotere rol is gaan spelen in deze snel ontwikkelende wereld, is het zeer relevant om ter plaatse kwalitatief onderzoek te verrichten. De 20 studenten gaan samen met de commissie in het najaar van 2018 naar Singapore, waar zij in duo’s zes weken lang veldwerk zullen verrichten om data voor hun eigen onderzoek te verzamelen.

column1: In maart 2018 wordt er een groep van twintig studenten geselecteerd. In periode 4 van het collegejaar 2018-2019 en in periode 1 van het collegejaar 2018-2019 volgen zij wekelijks onderwijsbijeenkomsten waarin zij voorbereid worden op het onderzoek. De bijeenkomsten in periode 4 gaan in op het thema, het perspectief ‘van plan naar praktijk’ en zullen de duo’s in de laatste bijeenkomst een duurzaamheidsinitiatief uit Singapore presenteren in de vorm van een TedTalk aan de medestudenten en organisaties die raakvlakken hebben met het thema. De bijeenkomsten in periode 1 gaan in op de Singaporese context, het doen van onderzoek en het schrijven van het wetenschappelijk artikel. Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij in periode 4 en 1 de opgegeven literatuur voor de onderwijsbijeenkomsten bestuderen. De voorbereiding van het traject wordt afgerond met twee opdrachten: een elevator pitch en een onderzoeksvoorstel. Daarna reist de groep voor zes weken af naar Singapore om onderzoek te doen. Bij terugkomst in Nederland wordt een wetenschappelijke artikel geschreven in het Engels aan de hand van het onderzoek en worden deze door de commissie samengevoegd in een bundel. Deze bundel wordt uitgebracht op het symposium in het voorjaar van 2019 waar alle duo’s ook hun onderzoek zullen presenteren. De studenten sluiten het Research Project niet alleen af met een wetenschappelijk artikel, maar ook met een individueel reflectieverslag.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/190024,2018,Internet and medicines,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,[],,Course goals
Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om
• de problemen die internetgeneesmiddelen veroorzaken te schetsen en aan te geven wat de gevolgen zijn voor patiënt en maatschappij.
• een beeld te geven van de motivatie voor het bestellen van internetgeneesmiddelen en is in staat om de patiënt te waarschuwen en te adviseren op het gebied van internetgeneesmiddelen
• de kwaliteit van een internetgeneesmiddel te bepalen door het opstellen en uitvoeren van een analyseplan
• de verschillen in nationale en internationale wetgeving op het gebied van (internet)geneesmiddelen te schetsen en is zicht bewust van de beperkingen van de wetgeving
• de nieuwste technologieën die worden ingezet in de strijd tegen internetgeneesmiddelen te begrijpen en toe te passen
• inzicht te tonen in de processen rondom (wereldwijde) geneesmiddeldistributie en kan de zwakke plekken in de keten aanwijzen

• de methoden die gebruikt worden voor het bepalen van omvang en schade van het gebruik van internetgeneesmiddelen op gezondheidsgebied en economische gebied toe te passen en het onderzoek te begrijpen/in te schatten

De handel in illegale geneesmiddelen is niet nieuw maar heeft sinds de opkomst van internet een enorme vlucht genomen. Hoewel het probleem in Nederland klein is ten opzichte van veel andere landen, blijkt uit verschillende onderzoeken dat ca 10% van de Nederlanders wel eens geneesmiddelen bestelt via internet. Het is de taak van Nederlandse overheid maar ook van de apothekers om de consument te adviseren en te waarschuwen voor de gevaren van het bestellen via internet. Deze adviserende rol vereist uiteraard wel dat apothekers op de hoogte zijn van de gevaren en weten waar ze alert op moeten zijn. De illegale handel in internetgeneesmiddelen kent vele kanten: o.a. juridische, technologische, analytische en logistieke facetten spelen een rol. Daarnaast heeft de apotheker een adviserende functie naar de patiënt toe. Binnen deze cursus zullen de studenten kennismaken met de problematiek omtrent internetgeneesmiddelen waarbij de verschillende facetten aan bod komen. Aangezien de markt zich de laatste jaren heeft uitgebreid naar medische hulpmiddelen, zullen ook deze aan bod komen.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/185711,2018,Internet Social Media and Networks,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. R. Corten'],,Course goals
<li>the student is familiar with core concepts from social network theory
<li>the student is familiar with some important research methods for the analysis of social networks
<li>the student is familiar with the most important research questions, theories, and social research findings in the field of the internet and social media
<li>the student is able to translate specific contemporary social problems and policy issues into relevant research questions in the field of the internet and social media
<li>the student is able to use specialized software for social network analysis and visualization for basic analyses
• the student is familiar with common data collection methods in the field of online social interaction.

The internet plays an increasingly important role in modern societies. More and more, social interaction, between individual people, but also between consumers and producers, and citizens and the government, takes place online. These developments imply many new sociological and societal questions, but also provide opportunities for new research and new policies. For example, does the emergence of the internet hinder or promote social cohesion in the sense of intergroup contact? Does internet usage foster loneliness? What is the impact of formal and informal online social networks on the effectivity of organizations? &nbsp
column2: What is the role of the internet in the self-organizing capacity of political and social movements?

column1: Some of these questions relate to long-standing sociological questions and theories for which the internet provides new and exciting testing grounds
column2: other questions require new theory altogether.In any case, the richness of digital data generated by online social interaction provides unprecedented opportunities for social scientists to study new and old research questions in innovative ways, and thereby to contribute to the solution of important social problems.&nbsp

column1: It turns out that many of these questions can be fruitfully studied from the perspective of social network analysis. In this course, students learn how to apply theories and methods from social network analysis to questions about the internet and social media, in the context of contemporary social problems. Methods of data collection in online social contexts, use of specialized software, and ethical issues will also be discussed.
Completing the Masters programme in Sociology: contemporary social problems provides students with:
Knowledge and understanding in the area of defining problems, theories, research and policy:

column7: Important theories and models for examination of current social issues

column1: specific knowledge and understanding in relation to one of the tracks on offer, specifically:&nbsp

column3: Health, Policy and Organisations track: key concepts from the governance &amp
column4: network theory in relation to health issues

column3: Crime and Safety track: key concepts in criminology in relation to public security issues
Internet, Social Media and Networking track: key concepts from social network theory in relation to social issues.

column8: Analyse complex questions from a sociological/interdisciplinary/comparative theoretical perspective and relate these to scientific and social debates.
Translate/apply new and previously acquired socio-scientific knowledge to current social issues.
Operationalise theoretical, methodological and practically-oriented understanding in a feasible research proposal.

column7: Carry out independent research, draw conclusions from it in written and spoken form in a clear, straightforward manner to present to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.

column9: Create a link between scientific knowledge, research questions and practical issues.

column8: Provide a client with responsible advice on policy or organisation.

column1: Form judgements about scientific­, societal and ethical aspects.

column8: Reflect on developments and discussions in science and society with regard to current social issues, on the basis of well-founded theoretical, analytical, methodological and practice-oriented considerations.
Critically reflect upon information they have gathered themselves on current social issues based on theoretical, methodological, practice-oriented and social considerations.
Adopt an honest and critical position in relation to research plans and results.

column7: Think critically about the professional ethics of people working in sociology within a wide social context.
Report, independently and in an academically sound way, on their own activities and present clear recommendations to interested parties both verbally and in writing.

column8: Report the results of their own research, or advice, to clients or others working in the field verbally and in writing in a clear and structured manner.

column7: Reflect upon professional ethical issues within their future professional field.
Deal with ethical aspects in a well-considered manner as an academic professional.

column1: The topic could be theoretical or practical, could include fieldwork and/or lab-work and/or computer-based simulation/modelling. The various options include: a work placement in a company or government organisation working in Earth Sciences or participating in university research. In consultation with the proposed supervisors - one internal supervisor (teacher) and one external supervisor (from the organisation offering the training), a traineeship proposal should be formulated. This should also contain details of credits involved (ECTS), time-planning, deliverables (reports/presentations), confidentiality aspects etc. to avoid last-minute surprises on all sides. The traineeship request form and proposal MUST be submitted for PRIOR approval to, first, the internal supervisor, and then the traineeship coordinator of the relevant MSc-ES programme who will pass it on to the board of examiners for final approval. If the traineeship is also to be used for the mandatory graduation research, the traineeship proposal should also be submitted to the coordinator of the relevant MSc-ES programme for PRIOR approval.

According to the examination rules and regulations with regards to the MSc programmes Hydrology and Physical Geography, a student should first hand in a first version of his/her MSc graduation thesis before he/she is allowed to start off with a traineeship.
More information and required forms are available on website: enter the page for your master programme and look for “internship”.

column1: The internship enables students to acquire hands-on experience with linguistics research in an ongoing project headed by a senior researcher. The aim is to practice research, academic and communicative skills the students have been equipped with during the RMA programme, and to prepare them for carrying out their own research in the RM thesis. Therefore, the internship follows (most of) the electives, and precedes the thesis. The internship may but need not be directly connected to the student’s thesis, by providing, for instance, a pilot experiment or preliminary data/corpus collection that will be improved and further worked out/analyzed in the thesis or a critical evaluation of theoretical background. &nbsp
A substantial component involves writing scripts (simple programs) in the Python programming language.&nbsp
column2: We will learn how to use scripts to manage and analyze texts (“corpus analysis”), carry out searches that go far beyond what you can do with a standard web form, count words and constructions, create randomized experimental stimuli, etc.

column1: Students will become familiar with different types of digital language resources, and some of their uses in theoretical or experimental research.
The skills learned in this course can be applied to employment outside academia, in the domain of natural language processing. The programming component has even broader utility.

Together with the thesis, the research master internship constitutes the individual trajectory of the student. The exact activities/tasks, mode of working, schedule and expected outcomes may vary across individual internship projects, but they are all always agreed upon prior to the beginning of the internship and spelled-out in the written Trainee Agreement form. The Trainee Agreement form must be signed by the internal supervisors, the student and (if applicable) the external supervisor to be valid. Trainees can participate in ongoing research projects led by senior researchers that take place i) in-house, ii) at another research institution in the Netherlands, or iii) abroad. Students are responsible for finding their own supervisor, but are strongly encouraged to consult with the RMA tutor on their choice. In all cases the trainee must have an internal (UiL OTS) ) supervisor, who is responsible for filing the results in Osiris and sending the intern’s document to the Internship Office for archiving and safe keeping. All internships, even those predominantly oriented towards application and valorization must have a clearly defined component of fundamental/basic research in it. All internship projects must have two final deliverables: a) Research Paper – a paper presenting the research question(s), relevance, theoretical framework, methodology, result(s), outcome(s), and conclusion(s) of the research project and b) Reflection Report - a short report following the internship (2 A4 pages), reflecting upon the suitability and desirability of the research environment the internship took place in, be it for theoretical, experimental, or applied work. Both are submitted to the local (i.e. UiL OTS affiliated) internship supervisor, who bases the final grade on their combined content (in conjunction with a second, possibly external supervisor when applicable).
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia.</body>
experience and become acquainted with the challenges, methods, constraints and practices of professional life
learn to distinguish between theory and practice and experience the challenges between the two
initiate a professional network which may prove invaluable for their future career.

<body>An internship offers students the opportunity to gain experience of the world beyond academia. In certain fields, internships are essential for students proceeding to graduate studies, and they are highly recommended to all who wish to develop their practical as well as their theoretical skills beyond academia. Students may only undertake one internship as part of their UCU programme. A requirement of such an internship is that it allows the intern to reflect upon the work carried out within their academic program at UCU. This connection should be clearly outlined in the internship proposal.

Students carry out agreed tasks within an organisation such as a company, an NGO, or any other organisation they wish to work for. The nature of the tasks may vary according to the host organisation’s needs, as long as there is a possibility for the student to reflect on the work carried out, since after completion of the internship the student must write a report that connects the practical work undertaken with his or her academic program. Depending on the nature of the task, the student either includes this reflection in their final report, or as an appendix to the report.
An internship counts as a level 2 course. It consists of at least five weeks fulltime practical experience in an (external) organisation. It is taken as a P/F course, and counts as an elective.

A Departmental Internship that is academic in nature may count towards a student's major, is academically supervised, and is graded. Within the intership proposal procedure, a student can indicate if there is an academic component or not, after which the role of the internship in the curriculum will be apporved by the UCU coordinator or fellow. An Academic Intership is coded within the Department: UCHUMINT21, UCSCIINT21, or UCSSCINT21

Examples of academic internship activities: museum internships associated with cultural heritage (CHIP), compiling research literature, conducting archival research, writing computer scripts, processing data for a publication, etc.

A student wishing to do an internship must locate a host institution and local supervisor (to guide the work undertaken). Local sources such as fellows, the careers advisory officer, teachers and tutors may be consulted to offer advice on institutions and supervisors, but UCU cannot be asked to mediate formally in the process of finding an internship.

The task of the UCU coordinator is: a) guide and advise the student if necessary b) approve the grade and c) make sure the student uploads an electronic version of the report to the HandIn function of the Internship workspace.
Any student is at liberty to make their own arrangements
column2: there is no GPA limit. Students may also compete for a limited number of internships arranged by UCU as part of specific programs. These may have specific selection criteria and/or prerequisites.

column1: The consent of the UCU Career DEvelopment Officer is required for an internship to count as part of the student’s UCU curriculum. This consent should be given before the internship starts.&nbsp
column2: For this purpose, an internship agreement form should be signed by all parties involved. This agreement specifies the student’s tasks, prerequisites, supervision meetings, and the date the report will be handed in, as well as any physical, liability and financial constraints. As an appendix to the agreement, an internship proposal should be present,, specifying the content of the work.

column1: Forms for the internship proposal and for the internship agreement can be found on the UCU's student website: http://students.uu.nl/en/university-college-utrecht/academics/internships .
The internship report must include an overview of the tasks completed during the internship which is to be verified by the host supervisor
column2: a journal of activities, including summaries and conclusions of work-in-progress meetings.&nbsp
column3: The report should provide a contextualising introduction to the work undertaken
column5: and a personal reflection connecting the work to the academic program. Any results of the tasks performed (for example written texts, interviews) should be included in the report as appendices. The student is responsible for completing the entire paperwork (Internship agreement and proposal signed by all parties involved) before submitting it to the college administration.1The deadline for submission can be found in the academic calendar.

column1: The head/coordinator acts as an independent counsellor and may be consulted in case of problems in the course of the internship.
1. Name of the host institution, name host supervisor
3. Outline of envisioned tasks within the institution (50-100 words)
4. Indication of how the work will be carried out (50-100 words)
5. Indication of potential contribution to the institution (100-150 words)
6. Indication of how the practical work relates to the UCU curriculum (200-300 words)
7. timetable specifying the various stages of the internship, including the date for handing in the report

It is recommended that students carry out an internship in their second year at UCU, preferably during the summer break or during the winter break. Under certain circumstances, an internship may also be carried out as one of the courses taken during a regular semester.&nbsp
column2: Any such arrangements during the semester must be evaluated by the tutor in the context of the student’s total study plan.

column1: The report must be handed in within 3 weeks after the internship ends, respecting the thesis deadline that can be found on the academic calendar. One copy must be submitted to the host institution
column2: one to the UCU coordinator, and one to the Registrar. In addition, the student must submit an electronic version of the internship report, via Handin, to the Internships Workspace.

column1: The final P/F grade is determined by the host institution supervisor and endorsed by the UCU coordinator.

<body>After completion of the internship, the student:
• is able to independently apply scientific knowledge and academic skills
• is able to write a report in a format that is commonly used in the occupational field
• has acquired and developed relevant professional skills

Via an assessment form, the student's ability to apply scientific and academic knowledge and skills in an independent way is tested. Also, the development of professional skills is evaluated. In addition, the written report also reflects the extent to which the student has succeeded in applying academic knowledge. Finally, the report reflects the student's ability to write a clear and, if applicable, to the occupational field tailored format report of the findings and recommendations.</body>

During the master's internship, the student will work in the occupational or in the applied cognitive research field. The internship can be conducted either at the university or at a company or research facility outside the university. The internship allows for a wide range of activities. Without being complete, this may vary from conducting a pilot study, evaluating a (measurement) tool, analyzing data, developing a measuring tool, to performing a usability research. The deliverable will be decided on at the start of the internship. In most cases, the deliverable will be or be supported by a written report in which the result(s), conclusion(s) and possible recommendations will be presented.

To discuss the different possibilities and procedures students should contact the internship coordinator of the programme. It is a prerequisite that the internship coordinator approves the internship.

It is strongly advised to the student to start his/her search for a topic and/or institute of interest in a timely fashion. For more information, the student can contact the internship coordinators Stella Donker (S.F.Donker@uu.nl) and Jeroen Benjamins (J.S.Benjamins@uu.nl).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/194265,2018,Internship Child and Adolescent Psychology,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)', 'dr. A.E. Aleva']",,"Course goals

The objective of the internship is to explore the field of work for child and adolescent psychologists, to train skills and to gain knowledge and insights that beginning developmental psychologists in that field of work are expected to have. At the conclusion of the internship, the intern is expected to have gained sufficient skills, knowledge and insights to be able to accept a job in one of the fields of work in which child and adolescent psychologists are active.
The following are important learning objectives of the internship:
• to become familiar with a specific field of work, including the associated working culture and the position of the developmental psychologist within it
• to learn how to apply knowledge and skills that have thus far been gained only in a general or theoretical sense to concrete problem situations emerging within this field of work
• to receive training in a number of skills that could be expected of a beginning child and adolescent psychologist within this field of work
• to assess whether the student is capable of working independently as a child and adolescent psychologist at a basic level
The following are important learning objectives of the internship:
<li>to become familiar with a specific field of work, including the associated working culture and the position of the developmental psychologist within it
<li>to learn how to apply knowledge and skills that have thus far been gained only in a general or theoretical sense to concrete problem situations emerging within this field of work
<li>to receive training in a number of skills that could be expected of a beginning child and adolescent psychologist within this field of work
to assess whether the student is capable of working independently as a child and adolescent psychologist at a basic level.
The assessment of the internship is based on the knowledge, insights and skills that have been gained with regard to the field of work
column3: and on determining whether the student is capable of working independently as a child and adolescent psychologist at a basic level. Assessment aspects include the extent to which the internship objectives have been achieved, the quality of the academic skills and the academic justification of the internship process and the internship objectives. This assessment is performed based on a concluding meeting between the intern, the internship supervisor from the institution and the supervising lecturer
column4: an internship report, and a diagnostic report or other assignment that is relevant to the internship. For a diagnostic internship, one case must be completed according to the guidelines of the BAPD. This case will also be addressed in the assessment. The supervising lecturer determines the final mark.</body>

column1: Internships are completed at institutions in which child and adolescent psychologists are active, at research institutions and at the university (limited availability).
We distinguish two types of internships:

In a clinical internship students are prepared to work as a developmental / child and adolescent psychologist. Students will acquire and practice professional skills and actively participate in diagnostic assessment (intake, apply instruments, score and interpret test results, report to clients), intervention, and coaching of children and adolescents with mental health, behavioural, or learning problems.
a. Clinical internships in an institution with Dutch speaking clients (20 EC)
These internships are only open to students who have an&nbsp
column2: adequate proficiency in Dutch. This clinical internship will be most suitable for students who aspire to qualify for a job as a child and adolescent psychologist in a Dutch institution for children and adolescents with mental health, behavioural, or learning problems.

column1: Within this internship, students gain competence in conducting diagnostic research according to the diagnostic cycle, as described by De Bruyn and colleagues (2006). Students are expected to proceed through the diagnostic cycle a number of times during the internship. If possible, they are also expected to devote a portion of their time to actively carrying out treatments (i.e. support, supervision and the discussion of assignments).

In principle, this internship can be arranged in such a way that it fulfils the requirements set by the NIP for the basic registration in psychodiagnostics (BAPD). The BAPD is not a required component of the Master's degree programme, however, and there is therefore no guarantee that it can be achieved. Students are expected to make time available outside the study programme to write the BAPD reports. Moreover, this internship prepares students to follow post-academic education in The Netherlands as a healthpsychologist, school psychologist and the registration process for NIP Child- and Youth Psychologist.
b. Clinical internships for foreign students (15 EC)

Students who don’t master the Dutch language (sufficiently) may do their internship in an institution which prepares them to work as a developmental / child and adolescent psychologist, and where professionals and clients speak a language the students sufficiently master, for example an institution in their home country.

This internship is intended for students who wish to familiarise themselves with research- , policy- or innovation related professional activities. Students will actively participate in an ongoing mental healthcare-related project at a (governmental) mental healthcare organisation or university (limited availability!). Students will develop competencies that relate to different phases of the empirical cycle, such as literature review, data collection, data analysis, reporting, and implementing research results.
Requirements for achieving the aforementioned objectives include the following:

• Knowledge: of general social-scientific theories, of theories concerning normal and problematic development, of common therapeutic interventions, of theories concerning specific topics of research at the institution.

• Basic skills: e.g. diagnostic skills, interview techniques, written and oral reporting, basic skills with regard to various types of treatments, methodological and statistical skills, and skills relating to the implementation of results.
• The activities should be performed increasingly independently.
Note: Students who complete an internship of 15 EC have to attend an extra course (5 EC) in professional skills.

For example, within the area of mental healthcare, internships can take place in institutions for youth services, childcare centres (for children with mental impairments), hospitals and clinics for child and adolescent psychiatry. Internships within the area of education could include school advisory or guidance services, special education schools or national pedagogic centres. Institutions can be oriented towards the problems of individual children (as emerging through education), as well as towards the broader or systematic problems of groups of students and educational institutions as a whole. New possibilities include community teams in several municipalities. Research institutions are relevant within the area of policy and research. Examples include Trimbos and TNO, the research departments of external care institutions and departments within the university.
Students are responsible for finding their own internship positions.
Internships typically start in September. Note: Internships abroad have to be scheduled in the second half of the Master's programme.

It is vital that you start looking for an internship position in time. Students are advised to send their letters of application for internships beginning in mid-January before the start of the Master’s programme. Students will not be allowed to apply for an internship unless they have received conditional admission to the Master’s programme (i.e. it must be clear that they will be able to complete their Bachelor’s degrees before the start of the new academic year). It is strongly recommended to register early for the Master’s programme.

Once students have been accepted as interns at specific institutions, they should contact the internship coordinator in order to arrange the further procedure. For each student, a formal internship contract is concluded between the department, the internship institution and the student. With regard to the substantive arrangement of the internship, the student writes an internship plan, which is submitted to the internship supervisor and the supervising lecturer within the department.

When searching for internships, students may use the department’s internship bank, which contains addresses at which other students have previously completed internships. Starting in early January, an overview of internship positions is posted to the internship directory.

Students can also search through websites and their own networks. Internships at institutions that are not included in the internship directory must be approved in advance by the programme’s internship coordinator. Students should therefore submit their internships in a timely manner, so that the internship supervisor can assess whether the internship meets the requirements of the programme (see ‘Important requirements’).
<li>The institution offers an internship with a total duration of 420 hours (15 EC
column3: Research, policy and/or innovation internship ) to 560 hours (20 EC
column4: Clinical internships in an institution with Dutch speaking clients) to be completed within 6 months (i.e., three days per week).

column1: • The internship must offer the opportunity to learn activities and skills suited to the activities of a child and adolescent psychologist.

<li>Internship students have to work under supervision of a behavioural scientist who works at the institution which offers the internship. Internship supervisors in a clinical setting should have a university degree in developmental or child /adolescent psychology or in “orthopedagogiek”. In a research/policy internship the supervisor is an experienced academic (preferably PhD) researcher within the organization (policy internship)
column2: at the university the supervisor is a PhD researcher or PhD candidate at the university.

column1: • The supervisor has a working experience of three years or more.
• In addition to the internship supervisor, a supervising lecturer will be assigned to the intern. This lecturer has final responsibility for assigning the final mark.

• Fridays must be reserved for education at the university. Compulsory monthly internship supervision meetings are held parallel to the internship for the purpose of addressing internship-related topics.
Information is available in documents on the stagebank. For more information, questions and check of suitbality of an internship students can contact the stagecoordinator at StagecoordinatieKJ@uu.nl

In November/December 2018, an internship information session will be held for students who are interested in the CCAP Master’s programme for 2019-2020. An invitation will be posted on Blackboard. Students who are not (or who are no longer) registered at Utrecht University are advised to contact the internship coordinator at StagecoordinatieKJ@uu.nl in order to have an invitation to the internship information session and the criteria for approving internship positions sent to them.

Various internship documents are posted on Blackboard: internship regulations, guidelines concerning the internship report, an example of an internship work plan, the assessment form, the internship contract and the working methods for the NIP basic registration (BAPD).</body>

column1: The internship report is the most important assessment of the students' academic and professional development, in which they describe their experiences with and reflections on the internship. The internship report will be assessed by the academic supervisor and an independent second assessor, after the local supervisor has checked the validity of the statements therein. The student's professional development is guided by means of peer review and supervision meetings, an interim evaluation and a final assessment of the learning process by the local supervisor. In the local supervisor's final evaluation, the supervisor provides a grade that helps to determine the final grade. Students are primarily responsible for their own professional development, assisted by contributions from the local and academic supervisor and fellow students. In the internship report, students demonstrate their ability to provide a concise and academically grounded description of their activities during the internship and their resulting professional development.

Students are primarily responsible for finding and being accepted by a suitable placement organisation. The Clinical Psychology department maintains a database of internship organizations that are part of its regular network. However, students are also expected to actively search for a placement that meets the requirements. New placements must be approved beforehand by the internship coordinator.

The internship is a study component in which students do an active professional internship in the field of clinical psychology. During the internship, students learn to integrate theory, empirical knowledge, methodologies and their other academic skills into professional practice. It is important for Master's students to learn to reflect on their academic, professional and personal qualities. As a future professional, students are expected to demonstrate considerable self-management skills and be ready for the labour&nbsp
column2: market. Students will do their internship at an organization for basic or specialized mental healthcare (including medical psychology and rehabilitation departments). The program offers the opportunity to do either a clinical internship or a research internship related to mental healthcare. Work performed on a clinical internship can include diagnostics, treatment or needs assessment. During the internship, students will practice professional skills in these fields and, in doing so, start to develop a professional and academic attitude. Students are generally supervised by a healthcare psychologist or an experienced academic psychologist within the organization. The clinical internship also prepares students for a healthcare psychologist or psychotherapist post-Master's programme. Pay careful attention to the previous education requirements for both programs: see http://www.rinogroep.nl. The clinical psychology research internship is intended for students wishing to familiarise themselves with research-related activities and roles. Students actively participate in an ongoing mental healthcare-related research project at an organization, gaining experience with professional and academic skills connected to different phases of the empirical cycle, such as literature review, data collection, data analysis and reporting research results. Students are supervised by an experienced academic professional within the organization, preferably an experienced psychologist.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/191038,2018,Internship ID,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['Docenten onderwijsinstituut SD'],,Course goals

<body>Upon completion of the field research practical, you should have acquired conceptual, methodological and practical competency that will be useful for your career in applied research, in the development policy and practice sector, and other work fields that require analytical, data gathering, communication and project implementation skills as well as cross-cultural competences. You should also be able to appraise the status of research process and findings (in terms of validity, representativeness, methodological soundness) presented by others.</body>

The course is designed to train your skills in conducting fieldwork-based research of an applied nature related to international sustainable development. The fundamental question asked is: what are the actual impacts of development and sustainability interventions in developing regions of the global south? As such, the course prepares for the type of assignments that many graduates will asked to do in the course of their career: formulate and execute well-crafted research design following academic standards on a practical problem of equitable and sustainable development.

The major part of the assignment consists of a 9-week fieldwork conducted in a team of 3-5 students, in collaboration with local organization(s) based in Africa, Asia or Latin America. The issues investigated can be of theory or practice oriented nature, faced by academic community, particular groups or society at large. This also prepares you for the next year’s research for your Master’s Thesis Sustainable Development (GEO4-2321).&nbsp

Based on individual proposals completed in the preceding methods and research design courses, you are expected to complete a team proposal that defines the topic, approach, deliverables and individual researchers’ roles in the team. Each team will be under the supervision of an IDS staff member. Drawing on their fieldwork findings, students write an individual research report and a team report that synthesizes the individual reports. Strict deadlines are enforced.

The fieldwork needs to be self-financed. The expected cost includes the cost for the air ticket, visa, vaccination (if necessary), and accommodation during the fieldwork. The teaching department is not responsible for the loss of rent, which International students with a 12 months SSH-housing contract will face, during their stay abroad.</body>

<body>For the Legal Resarch Master, it is possible to do an internship as part of your ‘profile area’, i.e. as one of the three electives. As such it is possible to obtain 7.5 ECTS for your internship, provided that the following conditions are met:
<li>The internship is relevant for the development of your research profile

• The Dean of the Legal Research Master (who also acts as coordinator for the internships) approves of the use of the internship as an elective. To obtain approval, you should complete the internship approval form (goedkeuringsformulier), which can be downloaded from the LRM Blackboard page, and send it to the Dean of the Legal Research Master by e-mail (Ms prof. dr. J.H. (Janneke) Gerards, j.h.gerards@uu.nl).
<li>The minimum duration of the internship is 6 weeks full-time or 30 days part-time (with a weekly minimum of 3 days’ work)
<li>You receive supervision from the internship location and from a member of the academic staff of Utrecht University (to be approved by the Dean of the Legal Research Master)
• At the end of your internship, your supervisor at the internship location completes the evaluation form (evaluatieformulier), available on Blackboard

• You write an internship report (minimum 1500 words, maximum 2000 words) describing your activities and learning experiences, and connecting your internship to your research profile, to be assessed by your supervisor from Utrecht University.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/188312,2018,Internship MA Conflict Studies,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. G.J.C. van der Borgh', 'dr. J. Demmers', 'dr. M.A. Fumerton', 'dr. R.W.F.G. Sprenkels', 'G.E. Frerks', 'L.M. Gould, MA']",,"Course goals
<body>The general objective of the internship is to 'learn by doing' through engaging with professional practice in the field of CS&amp
- to set-up and apply a strategy to extract and gather data on a specific research theme
- to articulate your position vis-à-vis your work environment

- to critically assess and reflect upon your work environment by analysing the assumptions about conflict (e.g. conflict causes, dynamics, prevention, or resolution) that underlie the activities/ policies of the workplace and relate this analysis to the theoretical discussions as reviewed in the taught courses of the MA programme and/or more broadly the literature on Conflict Studies and Human Rights
- to articulate in writing what you learned from doing this internship that contributes to your skills and knowledge ‘mastery’ related to this Master’s in Conflict Studies &amp

In the space of this course you take an internship at an organization in the field of Conflict and/or Human Rights. Ideally, your internship provides you with empirical data upon which you base your Thesis project in study period 4.
Students arrange the internship themselves. Examples are CARE, INCORE, PAX, Cordaid, UNDP, War Child,&nbsp
column2: Permanent Mission to the UN in New York, UNCHR, Embassies and Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs, but also smaller, local NGOS 'in the field' (ranging from Kampala, Paris, Sarajevo, Belfast, Beirut to Pristina and Guatemala City).</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/188369,2018,Internship MA Contemporary Theatre, Dance and Dramaturgy",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. K.G. Georgelou', 'dr. L.W. Groot Nibbelink', 'dr. M.J. Kattenbelt', 'dr. S. Merx', 'L.L. Karreman', 'prof. dr. M.A. Bleeker']",,"Course goals

The aim of the internship is to gain practical work experience and to develop reflection on professional practice, under the supervision both of a staff member of the organisation and one's supervisor.
1. The internship (report) should reflect that the student has gained practical experience in his or her field of study and/or gained profound knowledge of a subset of the professional field.
2. The internship report (work field evaluation component) should demonstrate that the student is able to develop reflection on professional practice and on personal learning goals.

3. The internship report (research component) should demonstrate that the student is able to research a specific topic within the context of the professional field, and to communicate insights to a wider audience, consisting of both academics as well as arts professionals.

The internship allows the student to gain hands on experience in a practice of his/her choice, either within the field of theatre and dance (dramaturgy, education, programming, publicity, policy, criticism) or in research about theatre and dance. An MA Internship consists of both a practical and an academically oriented component in which the student employs research and/or reflexive skills. Ideally, this research benefits both the internship organization and the MA Thesis.
During their internship, students participate in practical and/or research activities&nbsp
column2: and develop reflection about them. Prior to the internship they design a plan in which they define their goal and research questions. Afterwards, they reflect on the answers they have found to these questions in a written report.

column1: This course can be followed either in combination with the MA Thesis throughout block 3 and 4 (lint option) or in block 4.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/188313,2018,Internship MA Programme International Relations in Historical Perspective,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent nog onbekend/To be announced', 'dr. S.F.M. Massink']",,"Course goals
- Applying acquired knowledge and skills in a practical working situation
- Improving your analytical and professional skills and social competiences in order to strengthen your position on the labour market &nbsp

<body>An internship of at least three months offers you the opportunity to test your knowledge and skills in practice. Keep in mind that international organisations like the EU or the UN, or the Foreign Ministry of your country cannot offer a job to everyone with a MA degree in IR. However, with your skills in gathering reliable sources of information, and using these to write in-depth analyses on a variety of policy issues in an understandable language, you have the right profile to start a career as a policy maker with every organization and agency in the profit and non-profit sector. An internship in the world of international politics is great, but a policy internship with a multinational, a bank, or a consultancy agency can be rewarding and valuable as well. Of course you may also want to test your skills in the world of journalism. And if you opt for an academic career contact applied research agencies like Clingendael, Center for Terrorism and Counter Terrorism and the Insitute of Military History.&nbsp
When having acquired an internship, please contact you MA coordinator who will assign you to an internship supervisor.
Note: you must have at least 20 credits for the category M (Master) before starting your internship, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16013 Ges-Globalisation and Global Governance (5 EC)
GKMV16015 Ges-Europe and the World (5 EC)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/188281,2018,Internship Master Philosophy – Applied Ethics,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J.P.M. Philips', 'dr. L.L.E. Bolt', 'dr. M.A. van den Hoven', 'dr. N. van Steenbergen']",,"Course goals

<body>Students are strongly recommended to take an internship in the programme in order to a) explore future career options and gain valuable work experience, b) to improve and demonstrate meaningful application of their knowledge and skills in applied ethics in practice, and c) develop a professional network for future employment.&nbsp

The internship can be a traditional or a research-oriented internship. The internship counts for 10 ECTS. All students who plan to do an internship contact the internship coordinator of the department (Bart Mijland, b.mijland@uu.nl), who can advise on how to find an internship, suggests a supervising lecturer and advises on procedures and requirements. Before the start of the internship students have to develop an internship workplan and fill in the contract. The intership will be completed by submitting a written report to the supervising lecturer. This report includes a reflection on the experience and learning goals, (proof of) deliverables, and a reflection on theory and practice. .

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/186267,2018,Internship Neuropsychology (Clinical Track),English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['L.L. Meijer, MSc', 'S.R. Boelema']",,"Course goals
<body>After finishing the clinical internship the student has accomplished:

• Fulfilling the complete neuropsychological-diagnostic process under supervision (consisting of: formulating hypotheses, (hetero-)anamnesis, planning and executing a neuropsychological test, scoring and interpreting the test results, writing a report, verbally reporting the test results and providing possible advice, if possible a short introduction to treatments)

The internship report reflects on the achieved personal and professional goals and the accomplished activities during the internship. If the student also fulfills the terms of the Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek (BAPD) of the NIP, this will also be registered in Osiris.

<body>The clinical internship consists of participating (under supervision) in the duties of a neuropsychologist within a clinic in which people with cognitive function disorders are diagnosed, treated and/or nursed. It concerns an external diagnostic internship in a clinic which is approved by the internship coordinator. A clinical internship should contain a minimum of &nbsp
column2: 60% diagnostic work. This is possible in a neurological, rehabilitation or psychiatric department of a (academic) hospital, rehabilitation centers, psychiatric hospitals or nursing homes. More information on specific neuropsychological internships can be received from the internship coordinator. Before contacting a possible host institution, it is advised to contact the internship coordinator first, so he/she can confirm that the place meets the specific requirements. In addition, supervision of the university is provided through an internship teacher, who will guide the student together with the direct mentor of the internship. At the end of the internship the grade will be determined which will be based on the grade given by the internship mentor and the internship report. The internship teacher and the intern will have a final meeting in which the report, consisting of a reflection on the achieved goals and accomplished activities, will be discussed. More information on the internship report can be found on Blackboard.

column1: Please note that students can apply for clinical internships until 1 March 2019. If the student has not found a clinical internship by this date, only research/innovation internships are open for application.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/186269,2018,Internship Neuropsychology (Innovation and Research Track),English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A. Keizer', 'dr. C. Ruis', 'dr. M.J.E. van Zandvoort', 'dr. N. van der Stoep', 'dr. T.C.W. Nijboer', 'I.M.C. Huenges Wajer, MSc', 'prof. dr. A. Postma', 'prof. dr. H.C. Dijkerman']",,"Course goals
<body>After completing the internship, the student has:

• become acquainted with the practical aspects of scientific research within clinical neuropsychology and acquired professional and personal skills that are important for functioning within this professional field.

• practiced with applying the research process within practice-oriented research. This starts with the development of a research question on the basis of literature review, setting up the research, collecting data, analysing and finally reporting the research findings. The full empirical cycle must be completed.
• gained experience in converting the research finding into a specific end product and being able to present this product in a skillful manner.

The student is assessed on 1) the internship, 2) a presentation on the final product and 3) a scientific report. Getting acquainted with the practical aspects of scientific research is tested in criteria 1 and 3. Practicing applying the research process is also assessed in criteria 1 and 3. Converting a research finding into a specific end product is assessed under criterion 2.</body>

Neuropsychology investigates the relationship between brain and behavior. On the one hand, students are involved in the development and testing of models about relation between the human brain and functions such as memory, language, perception, motor skills, attention, emotional functioning and intelligence. On the other hand, neuropsychology is focused on identifying cognitive deficits in people with neurological or psychiatric disorders and developing treatment methods.

Within the innovation internship Neuropsychology, the student will gain experience with the innovation and implementation of methods for neuropsychological assessment and treatment. The internship focuses on activities that contribute to improving the quality of assessment or treatment within neuropsychology, based on the principles of empirical research. Examples of projects within the innovation internship are:
- use of virtual or augmented reality in assessment and treatment of neuropsychological disorders
- collecting norm data for new neuropsychological tasks
- evaluation of training programs such as neurofeedback
- research into the digitization of neuropsychological methods

The innovation internship can be done both at and outside the university. The internship coordinator has a list of available projects. In addition, it is possible that students find an internship on their own. When doing so, it is advisable to consult with the internship coordinator at an early stage. More information on specific innovation internship projects will also be announced on Blackboard.
• academic thinking, working and acting as a neuropsychologist
• placing the neuropsychological professional practice in an ethical perspective
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/194025,2018,Internship Product Development,English,Faculty of Science,,['drs. F.W. van Dam, MSc']",,"Course goals
<body>At the end of the course a student can
• give a general overview of the field of science communication and its knowledge base
• work in a project-based way and carry out relevant analyses for the product development task
• in a research based way, develop an educational / communication product, based on the science communication knowledge base
• evaluate developed product as well as design process
• get in touch with client and target audiences in a proper way and maintain good relations
• on the basis of pre-set learning aims, reflect on his / her own learning process / professional development

<body>In this course, you will get a general overview of the field of science communication and its knowledge base, and you will implement that information during your internship. You will be working in a science communication or education organization, while at the same time you will follow (some) educational sessions at university. You will experience this work environment, carry out all kinds of relevant tasks, seek active contact with the target audience(s) and meanwhile work on one main task: developing a concrete communication / education (CE) product for your organization / supervisor. This CE product will be designed using literature and has to be finished and handed in together with a (research- or evidence-based) report on why and how the product was made. In addition, you will have to reflect on your own professional development by means of learning aims which you have set up for yourself at the start of the internship. International students, please note that it may not always be possible to organize a product development task with an organization other than Utrecht University.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192181,2018,Internship Public International Law,Dutch, English","Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

• You can do an internship after you have successfully completed all the courses of the LLM, and after you have completed your thesis. If you need to be enrolled as a student for the duration of your internship, you may ask, after completing the thesis writing process, for postponement of your graduation. For more information on how to do this, please contact the internship coordinator.

• You can also do an internship at the same time as you are drafting the thesis. You can do this when the internship directly relates to your thesis topic, or when it is impossible to do the internship after finalizing the thesis. Before you apply for such an internship, please consult with the thesis coordinator.
<li>It is possible to get ECTS for your internship, provided the internship meets the following criteria:
<li>The internship must have an international law component
<li>The minimum duration of the internship is 6 weeks full time or 30 days part time (with a weekly minimum of 3 days’ work)
<li>During the internship, you will receive supervision from the internship location and from a member of the academic staff of Utrecht University
<li>Once you have found an internship, you need to fill in the internship approval form (goedkeuringsformulier), which can be downloaded from this Blackboard page

• At the end of the internship your supervisor at the organization where you have been working needs to fill in the evaluation form (evaluatieformulier), available in English and Dutch on this Blackboard page.
